awd_titl_txt: E2CDA: Type II: Memory, Logic, and Logic in Memory Using Three Terminal Magnetic Tunnel Junctions
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern processors dissipate at least 100× more energy when reading memory than performing simple arithmetic. The origin of this "memory wall" is the increasing gap between processor and memory speeds. Systems dissipate power making up for this speed gap with support logic such as caches, and further power is consumed in unused processor cycles while waiting for memory. One potential solution is to use spin rather than charge to store and process information. The dual capabilities of spintronics in logic and memory will be used to address the "memory wall" in two tasks: first by reducing memory write times from ~10ns to 1-10ps, and second by incorporating some logical functions directly within memory arrays. The focus will be to demonstrate multiply and accumulate circuits the foundation of all logic systems, but optimized here for convolutional neural networks. Industrial connections will be fostered through research visits from industrial researchers and the placement of students for internships and eventual employment. The additional aims of the educational mission are: 1) to inspire career interest of K-12 students in science and engineering; 2) to provide undergraduate students with cutting-edge research opportunities; and 3) to prepare students for future engineering careers through curriculum development and interdisciplinary collaboration. 

The technical goals of this program will be realized using new techniques for the interrogation and electrical manipulation of synthetic antiferromagnets, thereby enhancing the speed of magnetic tunnel junction logic and memory. Overcoming the material challenges of integrating topological and magnetic insulators will reduce the energy dissipation towards thermodynamic limits. The combination of low switching energy via efficient spin current generation in topological insulators, and fast switching in synthetic antiferromagnets is expected to deliver energy-delay products below 1fJ.ps.

por.por_cntn:
The main focus of the project is to develop magnetic switching device and circuit for overcoming the increasing gap between the performance of processors and memory in speed and power consumption. We exploited the dual capabilities of magnetic tunnel junctions in logic and memory devices to address the issues mentioned above.

The intellectual merit of this program is reflected in the results obtained under the two themes: first, we optimize materials and device structure of magnetic tunnel junctions which will increase the speed and lower energy consumption of non-volatile memories to the same level as main stream cache memory. Second, ?logic in memory? architecture is studied using magnetic tunnel junctions to perform logic within memory arrays.

More specifically, we have achieved the following results during the whole period of the program:

First of all, for material and device development of MTJ, we achieved : (1) spin orbit torque induced switching in nearly compensated rare earth-transition metal alloy ferrimagnet electrode. The spin orbit torque efficiency gets to the maximum value in nearly compensated samples, which makes it a very promising candidate for magnetic free layers in memory or memory in logic device. (2) Ultrafast current induced domain wall motion in a compensated ferrimagnet CoTb alloy. The current-induced domain wall mobility reaches a maximum at the angular momentum compensation point and exceeds that of ferromagnetic systems. (3) Demonstration of topological insulator induced magnetic switching at room temperature. Compared with previously studied spin Hall metals, topological insulators exhibit orders of magnitude improvement in switching energy efficiency. (4)  New oxide compound with high spin torque efficiency and good compatibility with magnetic insulators were studied. A very high spin Hall angle (~100%) could be achieved in semimetallic iridate compound SrIrO3. (5) To avoid shunting current in SOT switching and improve the energy efficiency, we synthesized ferrimagnetic insulator garnet thin films, including EuIG and TbIG thin films using PLD, which exhibited uniaxial PMA. (6) We demonstrate that high quality films with perpendicular anisotropy can be obtained by depositing these garnets onto Si substrate, and strong Hall effect from spin Hall magnetoresistance can be obtained from bilayer films composed of these garnet films and Pt metal layer. (7) Ultrafast domain wall motion was demonstrated in ferrimagnetic insulator systems, bismuth garnet BiYIG which shows even higher domain wall speed (up to 4.3 km/s) and more promising application prospect for low energy devices, compared with devices made from metallic materials.

The second theme of our center task of is to use three terminal MTJs to perform logic within memory arrays. To realize this goal, we have focused on the fabrication and electrical testing of the domain wall MTJ devices for neuromorphic computing. (1)  we conducted experimental and computational work on domain wall behavior in very narrow magnetic wires and analyzed the influence of magnetic wire roughness onto the magnetic bit precision. (2) We successfully developed MTJ film stacks and achieved TMR up to 50% out of MgO based MTJs. With the MTJ stacks, we designed and fabricated two different types of devices: synaptic function generators and threshold function generators. Successful electrical reading and writing are realized in those two categories of devices. We realized linear dependence between the writing current and MTJ resistance in the first group of devices, as well as nonlinear relationship between the programing current and device resistance in the second group. The versatility of these magnetic domain wall devices for both computation and memory suggests that it is an excellent candidate for use in neuromorphic accelerators. (3) We evaluated the influence of noise and limited states onto the performance of convolutional neural network which employs analog memory devices such as MTJs. The feasibility to reduce the weights and activations to 8-bits in modern deep convolutional neural network architectures such as AlexNet, GoogleNet and MobileNet without impacting the performance accuracy on the ImageNet image classification task was explored

Besides the progress in areas of material development, physics mechanism study, device fabrication, modelling and electrical testing, our project has also exerted broader impact onto the microelectronics industry, by developing new material and devices, as well as by strengthening the industrial connections through research visits and the placement of students for internships and eventual employment. Our research activities has brought in impact to the society and other disciplines through outreach and education activities including: 1) inspiring career interest of K-12 students in science and engineering; 2) providing undergraduate students with cutting-edge research opportunities; and 3) preparing students for future engineering careers through curriculum development and interdisciplinary collaboration.
